subject: RE: [junit] Testing Connection Pools
msgSnippet: I don t know which connection pool you on about but I know how my own connection pool works.  When a connection is returned it checks the transaction and rolls
messageBody:
I don't know which connection pool you on about but I know how my own connection pool works.  When a connection is returned it checks the transaction and rolls it back it one is open "SELECT @@trancount" on SQL Server.  This also serves the purpose of making sure the connection is OK, i.e. no network cables pulled out etc.  If the connection is working then its put back in the pool.  If the connection is faulty then it is closed and removed from the pool.
 
Not sure how you make sure all connections are returned.  Could do with a way to signal all sub-systems to return any connections and then check that none are still checked out of the pool.
 
Dave

>For software quality two of the most important things to test for
>(if you can) are:
>1. Connections are 'clean' when you put them back in the pool.
>The next piece of code to use the connection should be able to
>do so without fear of picking up a bad connection or one which
>wasn't tidied up properly by the last user.

Just out of interest, (and getting a little OT) is there any way to check
(within the code - not as a unit test) that the connection is "clean" - ie
ResultSets, statements closed etc.?



Jim
